confession.seduction_context: Very angry that her husband had gone off to the wars. Promised her money, and she gave in 'fort legerement'.

witnesses.name: Barbe femme Idoul Odinat
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: former tenant of property owned by accused's late husband

testimony.quarrel_subject: Building collapse - accused made angry and threatening remarks when witness was helping her husband replace tiles
Accused was angry that witness had not called her when she made a 'buée'
Accused was angry when his wife was too busy to put some lettuces with her own

harms_alleged.target: Jean de la Court and wife

witnesses.name: Anthoine Gerard
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: former tenant who lived in her house

testimony.quarrel_subject: Accused often quarrelled with his wife
Witness told accused that Demenge Potier would not arrest her if she gave him her 'jazerant d'argent'; she was very displeased
testimony.threat_quote: If he bought a horse he would have no luck, and his father had been ruined like that

testimony.quarrel_subject: Witness refused to let accused be godparent, only invited her to feast; accused would hardly speak a word for anger

witnesses.name: Jennon femme Nicolas Parisat
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor; Demenge Charpentier (accused's first husband) was godfather to their daughter

testimony.quarrel_subject: Witness had quarrel with accused; daughter did not want to call her godmother
Had various disputes while living together
Argument over a bed she was renting from the accused
Bought goods from accused to be paid in bread and commodities; when asked to make reckoning witness said she was not ready

witnesses.name: Jean Pierson
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: former tenant who lived in her house

testimony.quarrel_subject: Witness had quarrelled with his brother Nicolas; accused told him to let brother run, that they were very haughty but would not be so for long
testimony.threat_quote: qu'il le laisse courir, qu'il estoit bien hault luy et sa femme, mais qu'en peu de temps, ilz ne seroient tousjours sy haultain

witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor; accused came to fetch wine

witnesses.name: Idoul Odinat

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after she touched him on shoulder

witnesses.name: Jennon femme Nicolas Fournier

testimony.threat_quote: He would not come back yet (when husband was returning from festival)

timeline.subject: Dion veuve Jean Remy
timeline.details: Demenge Potier declares himself partie formelle

timeline.subject: Dion veuve Jean Remy
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Dion veuve Jean Remy
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; confessed after being racked

timeline.subject: Dion veuve Jean Remy
timeline.details: Confirmed confession; provided details about sabbat

timeline.subject: Dion veuve Jean Remy
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

accomplices_named.name: Annon femme Jean Clauderat
accomplices_named.context: Recognized at sabbat; only person she identified

prior_accusations.context: 35 years before trial; Nicolas Barbier died and widow suspected Dion; he had passed in front of her house just before sudden illness after a previous quarrel

notable_quotes.speaker: Dion veuve Jean Remy
notable_quotes.french: qu'il y avoit plus de sept ans qu'elle le pryoit et qu'il ne luy avoit rien faict, qu'elle voyoit bien qu'il ne la vouloit garder, ou elle debvoit aller, et qu'elle ne pardonneroit les personnes, qu'elle ne s'en soucioit de sa part, et que la justice estoient des meschants gens
notable_quotes.english: That she had been praying to God for more than seven years and he had done nothing for her, that she could see he did not want to protect her, wherever she must go, and that she would not pardon the people, that she did not care on her part, and that the justice were wicked people
notable_quotes.context: Complained to witness Babon when she came to fetch wine, hearing she was to be arrested

notable_quotes.speaker: Dion veuve Jean Remy
notable_quotes.english: That she would still be burned enough
notable_quotes.context: Said when a coal fell on her in neighbor's house; gave witnesses poor opinion

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Pierson (quoting Dion)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il le laisse courir, qu'il estoit bien hault luy et sa femme, mais qu'en peu de temps, ilz ne seroient tousjours sy haultain
notable_quotes.english: Let him run, he and his wife were very haughty, but in a short time they would not always be so proud
notable_quotes.context: Said about Jean Pierson's brother Nicolas before he became ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Dion veuve Jean Remy
notable_quotes.french: sy a tout coup lors qu'il y a des personnes malades, on vouloit les charger d'en estre cause qu'il en y auroit plusieurs mal a propos
notable_quotes.english: If suddenly when there are sick people, one wanted to charge them with being the cause, there would be many wrongly accused
notable_quotes.context: During interrogation, defending herself about Anthoine Gerard's child

notable_quotes.speaker: Dion veuve Jean Remy
notable_quotes.french: femme de bien, et sy on luy faict plus grand tort, tant plus de merite aura elle envers dieu
notable_quotes.english: A good woman, and if greater wrong is done to her, she will have all the more merit before God

relationships.evidence_text: Wife of Colas Moictrier, Nicolas Moictrier also in Raon
Chrestofle Remy and his wife Zabel
Demenge Charpentier, first husband of accused, was godfather to their daughter Jennon

relationships.person1: Claudatte femme Jean de la Court
relationships.evidence_text: Claudatte femme Jean de la Court
Jennon femme a honnorable Nicolas Fournier archer des gardes de S.A.

economic_context.details: Multiple debt disputes: Demenge Potier owed 20 francs for 'casaque' sold to late husband; Claudon Quentin owed money for cow sold to late husband; Chrestienne femme Jean Tourneur owed for goods to be paid in bread and commodities. Accused had disposed of goods before trial so little found in inventory. One witness mentioned accused's valuable 'jazerant d'argent' (silver item).

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill near Rozieres while carting cloth, was at St Nicolas for 3 weeks, thought to be dying, then gradually recovered
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Building collapse; accused made angry and threatening remarks when witness was helping husband replace tiles

harms_catalog.harm_description: Had accident when carting cloth, with leg and thigh broken, bedridden at Baccarat for 19 weeks and at Raon for 22 weeks. Now on crutches and forced to beg for livelihood
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Same as above

harms_catalog.harm_description: Dysentery, which they could not cure for long time
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Accused was angry that witness had not called her when she made a 'buée', although witness claimed she had sent her son

harms_catalog.victim_name: Child of Jennon femme Gerard Godat
harms_catalog.harm_description: Dysentery
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Same as above

harms_catalog.victim_name: Child of Jennon femme Gerard Godat
harms_catalog.harm_description: One child died after dysentery
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Same as above

harms_catalog.victim_name: Pig of Jean de la Court
harms_catalog.harm_description: Lost a pig
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Accused was angry when his wife was too busy to put some lettuces with her own

harms_catalog.harm_description: He and his wife had been ill when they were neighbours

harms_catalog.victim_name: Wife of Jean de la Court
harms_catalog.harm_description: Both he and his wife had been ill
Knee swelled up painfully, then trouble spread over half his body. Was ill for 3 weeks, then gradually recovered. Later said to be 'mal St Anthoine'
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: She often quarrelled with his wife while he was working as a cobbler

harms_catalog.harm_description: Child fell ill and died in 2 days; accused said she hoped it would not die because they would suspect her
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: He and his wife did not like her to be near the baby, as she always wanted to be; she told neighbours about this

harms_catalog.harm_description: Expensive horse suddenly died on third time he took it out
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Wife told accused witness was going to buy a horse, to which she replied that if he did so he would have no luck, and that his father had been ruined like that

harms_catalog.victim_name: Child of Bastienne femme Colas Moictrier
harms_catalog.harm_description: Child fell ill, seemed to get worse after accused visited it; was dry as wood, but with stomach swollen, and died after a year
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness asked accused to feast but not to be godparent, and she would hardly speak a word for anger. Later brought a sheet to use for child

harms_catalog.harm_description: Suddenly lost her milk after birth of child
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Had not been invited to 'recor' after birth of child, although she was his sister-in-law
harms_catalog.method_alleged: After being invited to dinner with others, accused said milk would come back, as it slowly did

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill suddenly, unable to speak or eat for 3 days. Accused came and spent day next to girl, who then recovered
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness had quarrel with Dion; daughter did not want to call her godmother although Demenge Charpentier (accused's first husband) was godfather
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Accused caused illness then cured it by spending day next to girl

harms_catalog.victim_name: Child of Clemence femme Thomas Jacquat
harms_catalog.harm_description: Child became ill and then died within 3 or 4 days, with no-one knowing what was wrong
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Accused said Clemence had not asked her to childbed, although she was near neighbour, and they would see what came of this

harms_catalog.victim_name: Son aged 2 of Marguitte femme Demenge Voirat
harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill for 6 weeks, as if demented, so they had sometimes to hold him down, and he could get no rest
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Had lived with her and had various disputes

harms_catalog.victim_name: Small child of Clemence femme Thomas Jacquat
harms_catalog.harm_description: Child died after 2 week illness, 4 years before trial
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Argument over a bed she was renting from the accused

harms_catalog.victim_name: Claude (son of Chrestienne femme Jean Tourneur)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Saw enormous spider on his forehead, which he brushed off and could not find again; hand became swollen, then had 'grosses boteilles' over whole body, and was ill for 6 weeks, thought to be dying. Surgeon said he had never seen such an illness. When accused visited him she said he was only ill, and then he gradually recovered
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Bought goods from accused to be paid in bread and commodities; when asked to make reckoning witness said she was not ready. Son Claude aged 12 told her to leave house, which she did angrily

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became strangely ill, bedridden for 9 months, then slowly recovered, but had subsequently died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness had quarrelled with brother; accused told him to let brother run, that they were very haughty but would not be so for long

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell from his horse and was in bed for 3 weeks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Husband had been at festival at Gerberviller; when children said he was returning, accused told them he would not come back yet

harms_catalog.victim_name: Claudatte femme Jean de la Court
harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill for 7 weeks. When she wanted to leave house accused would try to force her to go back in. Later lost use of arms as if they were broken, and remained in this state for some 10 weeks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Had asked accused to dinner after birth of child; few days later accused alleged that witness had complained that women had paid her no attention since dinner. Witness denied saying this. When accused found her doing washing and said she was still working although she was ill, witness replied that if her legs were as good as her arms she would have no problem. Immediately lost use of arms
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Accused's hands were very cold and witness was so frightened that when she touched her she trembled all over

harms_catalog.harm_description: Was ill for 6 weeks after accused touched him on shoulder
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Husband had sold a cow to her late husband and had not been paid; after his death had quarrel with her over payment when he asked her to pay

harms_catalog.harm_description: Died after sudden illness; had passed in front of accused's house just before
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: She had hated him over a previous quarrel

material_culture.context: Demenge Potier asked Demenge Didon to tell accused that if she gave him this item he would not have her arrested
Demenge Potier had sold this to her late husband for 20 francs
Witness was helping husband of accused replace tiles when building collapsed
Accused was angry when Jean de la Court's wife was too busy to put some lettuces with her own
Demenge Didon bought expensive horse for 38 ecus that died
Accused brought Bastienne a sheet to use for child
Clemence femme Thomas Jacquat was renting a bed from accused
Chrestienne femme Jean Tourneur was to pay accused in bread and other commodities from their bakery
Accused made Mengeatte drink some wine to help restore milk; also came to fetch wine from house of Mre Pierre Charles
Accused suggested damping coarse cloth, warming it by fire, and putting it on breasts to restore milk
Idoul Odinat was now on crutches and forced to beg for livelihood after his injuries
Claudon Quentin had sold a cow to accused's late husband
Confession: Mre Persin gave her black powder to kill
Confession: Mre Persin gave her white powder to cure

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; where accused and most witnesses lived
Where Idoul Odinat became ill when carting cloth
Where Idoul Odinat was for 3 weeks when thought to be dying
Where Idoul Odinat was bedridden for 19 weeks after his accident
Where Nicolas Fournier had been at festival before falling from horse

historical_context.military_details: Accused was seduced by devil when 'very angry that her husband had gone off to the wars' - indicates military service or conflict 7 years before trial (c. 1610)
economic_hardship_indicators: Idoul Odinat now on crutches and forced to beg for livelihood
Accused had disposed of goods before trial so little found in inventory
religious_calendar_references: St Jean (feast day mentioned in testimony)
Chandeleur (Candlemas - accused would be 80 next Chandeleur)
Christmas (Charles Commis living in same house around previous Christmas)

legal_context.redress_outcome: Said she thought Jean Barron, then mre echevin, would pursue complaint against Demenge Potier on her behalf when he called her witch 18 months earlier; no action taken

hearsay_chains.content: Heard them say accused had caused loss of milk by witchcraft
Repeated wife's story of death of child
Told story of loss of milk by Zabel Remy
Father believed accused had caused him various losses
Heard them blame accused for death of child
Had conversation about horse, as reported by husband
Uncle Nicolas Barbier died and widow suspected Dion
Repeated wife's deposition with details of his accident
Had heard her called witch by wife of Nicolas Moictrier
Had heard accused called witch several times

emotional_state_notes: Found in a kind of trance around Christmas
Cried continually some nights, blaming remarks made by partie formelle
Jumped up in fury when Demenge Potier tried to seize property, took him by throat and tried to strangle him
Asked to be put to death as soon as possible after confession

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Said Anthoine Gerard's illness had been 'mal St Anthoine' (natural illness). Had not caused death of his child, and had loved it too much for that
Barbe Braconnier claimed that her mother and father had already been suspected of witchcraft

third_parties.name: Demenge Remy (wife of)
third_parties.context: Wife of Demenge Remy was executed as witch about 2 years before this trial

third_parties.name: Chrestofle Remy
third_parties.context: His wife Zabel lost her milk; both now dead. Accused was his sister-in-law

third_parties.name: Zabel (wife of Chrestofle Remy)
third_parties.context: Lost her milk after not inviting accused to 'recor' after birth; both now dead

third_parties.name: Nicolas (brother of Jean Pierson)
third_parties.context: Became strangely ill, bedridden for 9 months, then slowly recovered but subsequently died

third_parties.name: Widow of Nicolas (brother of Jean Pierson)
third_parties.context: Believed Dion had caused her husband's illness

third_parties.name: Nicolas Barbier
third_parties.context: Died 35 years before trial; widow Sebille suspected Dion

third_parties.name: Sebille (widow of Nicolas Barbier)
third_parties.context: Suspected Dion of causing husband's death 35 years before

third_parties.name: Colas Moictrier
third_parties.context: Husband of Bastienne (witness 7); openly accused Dion of being witch and causing illness of child

third_parties.name: Annon femme Jean Clauderat
third_parties.context: Already executed; only person accused recognized at sabbat

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a detailed trial record with 28 witnesses and extensive testimony. Key observations: (1) Accused was 79 years old at trial, making her one of the oldest accused in the archive. (2) Evidence of healing practices - she cured Zabel Remy's milk loss and cured daughter of Nicolas Parisat after making her ill, suggesting she was known as a healer. (3) Economic status appears poor - multiple debt disputes, disposed of goods before trial, creditor initiated prosecution. (4) Very long reputation as witch - up to 35 years mentioned by one witness, with consistent reports of 7-20 years. (5) Husband had gone 'off to the wars' 7 years before trial (c. 1610), which was the context for her alleged seduction by devil - indicates military conflicts in Lorraine during this period. (6) Physical violence during debt dispute - she attacked Demenge Potier when he tried to seize property. (7) Reference to previous witch execution (wife of Demenge Remy) about 2 years before. (8) Multiple instances of touch-based harm alleged (cold hands, touch on shoulder). (9) Spider as alleged method of causing illness to Claude. (10) Confession under torture mentioned 'mal St Anthoine' as natural explanation for one illness. (11) Confession mentioned being beaten by devil for refusing to use powders and resisting suggestions to harm people. (12) Asked to be put to death as soon as possible after confession.
